title.narrative: SWE-2008-286 Genetic diversity of malaria infections and risk of disease under changing transmission
SWE-2008-286 Genetic diversity of malaria infections and risk of disease under changing transmission

description.narrative: Understanding how immunity develops to severe malaria is essential, as severe malaria should be the primary target of intervention strategies. Plasmodium falciparum is a highly polymorphic organism and infections often consist of several concurrent clones. Persistent multiclonal asymptomatic infections have been associated with protection against mild malaria. The aim of this project is to investigate whether the diversity of infections in early childhood affect the risk of severe malaria. In Kilifi Kenya, a large birth cohort and continuous hospital registries, provide a unique setting to address this issue. Retrospective analyses of 3 monthly blood samples from cohort children admitted with severe malaria will be genotyped for number of clones and mixed species, and be compared to age matched community controls. Severe malaria risk and infection dynamics will be specifically assessed.

Understanding how immunity develops to severe malaria is essential, as severe malaria should be the primary target of intervention strategies. Plasmodium falciparum is a highly polymorphic organism and infections often consist of several concurrent clones. Persistent multiclonal asymptomatic infections have been associated with protection against mild malaria. The aim of this project is to investigate whether the diversity of infections in early childhood affect the risk of severe malaria. In Kilifi Kenya, a large birth cohort and continuous hospital registries, provide a unique setting to address this issue. Retrospective analyses of 3 monthly blood samples from cohort children admitted with severe malaria will be genotyped for number of clones and mixed species, and be compared to age matched community controls. Severe malaria risk and infection dynamics will be specifically assessed.
